It tells tales of amazing achievements of service users impressing suit wearing funders in the 'BIG GAME' of tick box. Staff get not even a 'thanks' for hours of being shouted at, cleaning client faeces (check stool chart), attacked, trying to budget shrinking weekly client living allowance, always acting 'positive' at work, thinking of CREATIVE ideas and spending any spare time trying to organise activity, etc, etc, etc, all of the time 'smiling' and believing we are doing something to help us into heaven. . .

Management operate on a tick-box cover their backsides blame system whereby if anything goes wrong, it's all down to the frontline staff "who've been told." Inductions consist of being told to read upwards of 1000 sheets of policy documents on your own with no support. Service Directors are rarely seen at individual services and often have no idea about the state of the services they are responsible for.

Communication between management and Support Workers is pretty much nonexistent. Appointments can be made for the service-users or changes to their timetables can be made without management relaying this information to staff, let alone the service-users themselves; electricians, gas technicians and district nurses turn up unannounced due to poor communication. Management don't want to know about your concerns, they're only bothered about keeping their bosses happy. If there's an audit of the service, management always miraculously catch wind of this the day or two before and run around frantically sorting things out. 

Expect to be put on incredibly long shifts i.e 9am until 11pm, a "sleep" from 11pm until 7am and then working a further 8 hours until 3pm. If anything happens during the night and you can't sleep as a result then don't expect to be paid anymore or be relieved by other staff members in the morning. 

Don't expect to be able to have a social life outside of work either. Rotas are most often than not completed at the very last minute so you can never make any plans as you might be working. Management also seem to have a knack of clashing the shift handover with client's regular activities so you are forced to work overtime, unless you're lucky and the next person on shift can meet you and the service-users wherever you may be. 

The service-users themselves suffer from poor management. If without family or a particularly caring Support Worker then service-users, especially those with learning disabilities are left without a voice. Service-user's homes are often left in a state of disrepair and are only ever sorted out unless absolutely necessary. 

Staff turnover at Creative Support is incredibly high and morale is low. They don't have a HR department, rather they have a few people at head office who deal with HR issues on top of their own work. How they've managed to bag the Investors in People accreditation I'll never know.

Sadly, I'm sure these problems are rife across the across the health industry. Privatisation has meant that "not for profit" organisations like Creative Support submit bids for tender for everything and anything, regardless of their ability to provide a good service. Councils will award the contracts to the lowest bidder and that's that. No one regulates the quality of service in any great depth and councils save money.
